findings.content: The Settlement Phase is a great place to start and end your game sessions. After survivors return from battle, players develop their settlement and spend resources before a new group sets off. Update the record of what you've earned so that you are ready to hunt when you return to the game. During the Hunt Phase a group of survivors departs from the settlement to track their quarry through the bizarre landscapes of Monster. The price of their failure is grim: if the survivors perish or return emp- ty-handed, the settlement will starve Hunting takes place on the hunt board, which acts as a stage for the chaotic events that befall the survivors while in pursuit of a monster Lethal risks and strange rewards await the survivors on the hunt. Even the journey to the battle can be potentially fatal. When hunting the monster, players take turns guid- ing the group through each event. Use this as an opportunity to create suspense and surprise. Read hunt events scenarios aloud without revealing the possible outcomes. Decide how to approach each situation, then make any rolls and face any outcomes together. Defeating monsters 1n the Showdown Phase 1s the primary way of gathering resources, evolving survi- vors, and passing lantern years. The Showdown Phase 1s the longest phase of the game, and requires the most in-depth coopera- The showdown consists of a battle between the en- tire group of survivors against a single monstrous intelligence. Each showdown m Monster is unique. Players take turns controlling the monster using a pair of randomized decks that govern its behavior. Monsters are also tough. # Settlement Phase is a great place to start and

> **Type:** Monster  
> **Source:** 02-core-rules-ocr.txt  
> **Confidence:** confirmed

---

## Overview

The Settlement Phase is a great place to start and end your game sessions. After survivors return from battle, players develop their settlement and spend resources before a new group sets off. Update the record of what you've earned so that you are ready to hunt when you return to the game. During the Hunt Phase a group of survivors departs from the settlement to track their quarry through the bizarre landscapes of Monster. The price of their failure is grim: if the survivors perish or return emp- ty-handed, the settlement will starve Hunting takes place on the hunt board, which acts as a stage for the chaotic events that befall the survivors while in pursuit of a monster Lethal risks and strange rewards await the survivors on the hunt. Even the journey to the battle can be potentially fatal. When hunting the monster, players take turns guid- ing the group through each event. Use this as an opportunity to create suspense and surprise. Read hunt events scenarios aloud without revealing the possible outcomes. Decide how to approach each situation, then make any rolls and face any outcomes together. Defeating monsters 1n the Showdown Phase 1s the primary way of gathering resources, evolving survi- vors, and passing lantern years. The Showdown Phase 1s the longest phase of the game, and requires the most in-depth coopera- The showdown consists of a battle between the en- tire group of survivors against a single monstrous intelligence. Each showdown m Monster is unique. Players take turns controlling the monster using a pair of randomized decks that govern its behavior. Monsters are also tough. Your group will utilize all of its weapons, gear, innovations, and survivor characteristics to their full potential to defeat each Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game 37 rersisr£1r1r Innovation D£"c.k lnriov.ihons aro socml and tochnolog,cal d1scoverios lhlll profoundly affoct lho futuro of your solllomonl Thay cnn grant new combat i1b11il1os, accoss 10 now rcsourcos . sottloment ac1,v,110s . and expand lho pos • ,t,,lities of 1he setllemont s future Each new 1nnovat1on 1s perm;rnently added lo tho i:otttemont Soltlement ,nnovat1ons are recorded on tho settlement rccord shoot ond slorod oport from The 1r1nova11on dock contains Iha settlement's polen- t1;il When survivors innovate. gaining cards from the dock to add to thelf soltlement. tho innovation deck grows Innovations direct you lo add new 1nnovat1ons to tile innovation deck as they are discovered As a result, the innovation deck 1s persistent, and grows un,quoly based on your settlement's de ets,ons There 1s a spec1at place in the box to store your settlements un,que innovation deck to keep track of 1t between game sessions. A story event ,s a moment in time s h players When a story event is triggered, every! ing that is currently happening in lhe game freezes Pass the game book to a player, turn to the in· d1cated story event, and read out loud what happens next Share tho full page artwork with everyone. Once lhe story evenl is resolved, and all outcomes have been recorded. the game unfreezes and any- thing that was happening resumes. Story events arise as survivors confront import- ant ph1losoph1cal dec1s1ons, explore and gather re- sources during the hunt, discover new monsters, and Each monster has a showdown story event that has all the information you will need to hunt and fight When you see the Ill icon, trigger the indi- cated story event right now! Story Events are listed on the settlement's timeline, on some monster cards, on tnnovattons, and even on the survivor record Milestones. indicated by heavy-lined unfilled boxes on the survivor and settlement record sheets, have s ecial rules that occur when they are filled in. Mile- s~ones can be reached by individual survivors and by As survivors gain hunt experience, they will reach milestones These milestones trigger the Age story event, which will increase the survivor's power. Sur- vivors also encounter milestones as they gain cour- age, understanding, and weapon proficiency.

findings.content: The Settlement Milestone Story Event section on the settlement record sheet includes many milestones. like the settlement's first birth, its first death and a game over when the population reaches O. When these milestones are reached , fill their box and im- mediately trigger their corresponding story events. ......... ~- ...,._,.._ __ _...,.,.,.,,.~~..........,.. Throughout the game, you will roll dice to determine the outcomes of everything from attacks to choosing When the game instructs you to roll d10s, it re- fers to the 10-sided dice included with the game. The values on the dice are 1 to 1O (the 1O face is repre- sented by a lantern). The number of dice you need to roll is specified by the number before "d1 O", so 2d10 is 2 dice. If the game instructs you to roll a d5, roll a d 1O and divide the result in half (rounded up). Rolling on tables is an important component of the game, introducing an element of chance to events. Many moments in the game are accompa- nied by a table , everything from determining the out- comes of severe injuries to the results of story events contains an element of chance. Some tables are even affected by existing inno- vations and principles the group has already chosen. Lantern 10 refers to a die roll result where the lantern face Is showing. Natural 1 refers to a roll result where the number "1'' face showing During the showdown, it is possible to encounter situations where It Is impossible to succeed or fail at hitting or wounding. In such cases, Lantern 1O's al- ways succeed and 1's always fail. This way, the pos- sibility of success or failure exists, even in the most one-sided circumstances. For instance, players may find themselves fac- ing monsters with toughness so high that the maxi- mum die result (10) combined with their strength Is not enough to penetrate the monster's toughness. In this case, when a lantern 10 Is rolled, it will still wound (and cause critical wounds, if luck allows). Conversely, monsters may face situations where an attack roll will always hit. For example, at- tacking a survivor with negative evasion mght mean it would hit on a 1 or higher.
